abstract.text: The goal of the study was to assess the Type I error rate, power, and accuracy of the methods that are used in the paper to estimate species niche width (measured as the generalized standard deviation of species occupancy density in niche space), niche overlap (measured as the pair-wise niche overlap statistic of the occupancy densities of both species in niche space), and significance of these statistics.

body_text.text: Cluster process parameter -Mean number of individuals in plot across years Cluster process parameter -Mean number of cluster centers in plot across years Cluster process parameter -Standard deviation of clusters in space Cluster process parameter -Standard deviation of clusters in time
The overall algorithm is as follows:

1. Simulate individuals of S species under the null hypothesis. Each species has random parameters drawn from the distributions shown in Table S1 . 2. Estimate niche width for S species and pair-wise overlap for (S(S-1))/2 species pairs, and assess statistical significance as per methods described in the paper (we used 1000 randomizations per test to assess significance). 3. Calculate the null hypothesis rejection rate as the proportion of species (in case of specialization) or species pairs (in case of overlap) identified as having statistically significantly small (in case of specialization) or either small or large (in the case of overlap) observed values. This is the Type I error rate.

The above steps are repeated for the alternate hypotheses, in which case the rejection rate gives us the statistical power of the corresponding test, which is, unlike in the case of the null hypothesis, typically a function of several variables representing sample and effect sizes. To calculate accuracy, the true niche width or overlap is compared to the estimated niche width or overlap.
The entire process is used to simulate data in and assess all three scenarios: spatial-only, temporal-only and spatiotemporal.

The null hypothesis for the niche specialization test is that species occupancy densities are d-variate uniform in niche space (i.e. "generalists" lacking any "preference" in niche space) but individuals nevertheless exhibit autocorrelation in world space (i.e. geographical space and time) due to reasons unrelated to environmental variation, such as limited seed dispersal. Specifically, autocorrelated locations of individuals are realized as a homogeneous spatio-temporal Neyman-Scott cluster process (Diggle and Gabriel 2010) .
body_text.section: Simulating data under the null and alternate hypotheses

body_text.text: The alternate hypothesis for niche specialization is that species occupancy densities are non-uniform in niche space ("specialists") and individuals exhibit autocorrelation in world space as before. Specifically, species occupancy densities are d-variate normal in niche space. For a given species, the (d-dimensional) mean of this d-variate normal is drawn from d separate normal distributions and the (d-dimensional) standard deviation drawn from d separate log-normal distributions. Species occupancy densities are first converted to occurrence densities by multiplying them with the density of the environment itself and then mapped back to world space to control the number of offspring points of an inhomogeneous spatio-temporal Neyman-Scott cluster process.
body_text.section: Simulating data under the null and alternate hypotheses

body_text.text: The null hypothesis for the niche overlap test, as in the case of the niche specialization test, is that species occupancy densities are d-variate-uniform in niche space ("generalists"), statistically independent of other species, but individuals exhibit autocorrelation in world space.
body_text.section: Simulating data under the null and alternate hypotheses

body_text.text: The alternate hypothesis for the niche overlap test is that species occupancy densities are non-uniform ("specialists") and statistically correlated with each other in niche space, and individuals exhibit autocorrelation in world space. Specifically, like in the case of the niche specialization test, species occupancy densities are d-variate-normal in niche space. For a given species, the (d-dimensional) mean of this d-variate normal is drawn from d separate S-variate normal distributions and the (d-dimensional) standard deviations are drawn from d separate log-normal distributions. The S-variate normal distribution of niche means has a covariance matrix with negative off-diagonal elements, which results in the means of species densities tending to be overdispersed in niche space (i.e. niche differentiation). The covariance matrix is built by first creating an S x S correlation matrix with 1 on the diagonal and -1 off the diagonal, and converting it to the nearest positive-definite matrix using the function nearPD() in the package 'Matrix'. Individual plant locations in space and time are simulated as described in the niche specialization case.
body_text.section: Simulating data under the null and alternate hypotheses

body_text.text: Calculation of the true generalized standard deviation and overlap statistics is achieved by first evaluating occupancy of the true niche functions on a high-resolution grid.
body_text.section: Simulating data under the null and alternate hypotheses

body_text.text: The function rpcp() in the package 'stpp' (Gabriel et al. 2014) , with a few modifications, was used to simulate the spatio-temporal Neyman-Scott cluster processes. All four parameters for the process (Table S1 ) for each species are drawn from uniform or lognormal distributions such that the range of values simulated is similar to the range of values obtained by fitting a cluster process to actual species data from the 50-ha plot using the function thomas.estK() in the package 'spatstat' (Fig S11) . body_text.text: The average Type I error rate across all scenarios, given a test size of 5%, was 6.1%. The remaining results are shown in figures.  Note that in all figures, the niche specialization tests will have fewer points (S = 150 species) compared to the niche overlap test ((S(S-1))/2 = 11,175 species pairs).  The "SxTy" notation throughout denotes the number of spatial dimensions (x) and number of temporal dimensions (y).  Results under the null hypothesis are shown in red and those under the alternate hypothesis are shown in green throughout.  In the statistical power figures,

Overestimation of small pair-wise overlaps is partly because spatiotemporal contagion (simulated by the inhomogeneous spatio-temporal Neyman-Scott cluster process) causes simulated individuals to be present at locations "outside" their niche. For example, even if the true overlap between species is zero, individuals of both species may occasionally land up on the same quadrat, resulting in observed overlap that is greater than zero. It is also partly because when data are mapped into niche space and densities estimated, individuals present at locations with slightly different environment variables tend to get lumped together into the same bins, increasing overlap.
